result.markdown:
--- output: html_document editor_options: chunk_output_type: console --- # Inferences about Two Dichotomous Predictors and their Interaction ::: {.cell} ::: ## Learning Objectives For models with dichotomous independent variables, you will learn: - Basic terminology from ANOVA framework. - How to identify main effects, simple effects, and interactions in table of means and figures. - How to link coefficients from interactive models with each coding system to table of means and figures (both directions). - How to calculate simple effects. - How to write up and display results. ----- ## An Example **Example:** Attitudes toward abortion as a function of sex and religion. Sex: Male vs. Female Religion: Catholic vs. Jewish Attitude: 1â€“10 with higher scores indicating more permissive attitudes Equal $n = 20$ in each cell ($N = 80$). ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
male female all
Catholic 3 5 4.0
Jewish 3 7 5.0
all 3 6 4.5
````` ::: ::: ----- ## Terms and Brief Definitions ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
male female all
Catholic 3 5 4.0
Jewish 3 7 5.0
all 3 6 4.5
````` ::: ::: **Common terminology:** One-way ANOVA, Two-way ANOVA, Three-way ANOVA; 2 X 2 ANOVA; 2 X 3 X 2 ANOVA; Factorial ANOVA. **Cell mean:** The mean of a group of participants at specific levels on each factor (e.g., Catholic men, Jewish women, etc.). **Marginal mean:** The mean of cell means across a row or column. **Grand mean:** The mean of all cell means. **Unweighted vs. weighted means** ----- ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
male female all
Catholic 3 5 4.0
Jewish 3 7 5.0
all 3 6 4.5
````` ::: ::: **Main effect**: The *average* effect of an IV on the DV across the levels of another IV in the model (The effect of an IV at the average level of another IV). Evaluated with marginal means for IV. **Simple effect**: The effect of an IV on the DV at a specific level of the other IV. Evaluated with cell means for focal IV at specific level of other IV (moderator). **Interaction**: The simple effect of a (focal) IV on the DV differs across the levels of another (moderator) IV in the model. ----- ## Describing Effects ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
male female all
Catholic 3 5 4.0
Jewish 3 7 5.0
all 3 6 4.5
````` ::: ::: Describe the magnitude of the **main effect** of sex on attitudes. ----- Women have 3 points more permissive attitudes about abortion than men. ----- ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
male female all
Catholic 3 5 4.0
Jewish 3 7 5.0
all 3 6 4.5
````` ::: ::: Describe the magnitude of the **main effect** of religion on attitudes. ----- Jews have 1 point more permissive attitudes about abortion than Catholics. ----- ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
male female all
Catholic 3 5 4.0
Jewish 3 7 5.0
all 3 6 4.5
````` ::: ::: Describe the magnitude of the **simple effects** of sex on attitudes. ----- Among Catholics, women have 2 points more permissive attitudes about abortion than men. Among Jews, women have 4 points more permissive attitudes about abortion than men. ----- ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
male female all
Catholic 3 5 4.0
Jewish 3 7 5.0
all 3 6 4.5
````` ::: ::: Describe the magnitude of the **simple effects** of religion on attitudes. ----- Among men, there is no different in attitudes between Jews and Catholics. Among women, Jews have 2 points more permissive attitudes about abortion than Catholics. ----- ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
male female all
Catholic 3 5 4.0
Jewish 3 7 5.0
all 3 6 4.5
````` ::: ::: Question: Does there appear to be an interaction between sex and religion? Why or why not? ----- Yes, there does appear to be an interaction. The simple effects of sex appear to be different across Jews (4 points) than Catholics (2 points). Alternatively, the simple effects of religion appear to be different across women (2 points) and men (0 points). Of course, you can't tell if the interaction is significant by looking at the data descriptively, you have to test the interaction. ----- ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
male female all
Catholic 3 5 4.0
Jewish 3 7 5.0
all 3 6 4.5
````` ::: ::: Question: How might you quantify the magnitude of the interaction? ------ The simple effect of sex increases by 2 points from Catholics (2) to Jews (4). The simple effect of religion increases by 2 points from men (0) to women (2). This will be the parameter estimate for the interaction! ------ You have learned that there are two common options for coding the regressors for categorical IVs: *Dummy* codes and *Centered* codes. **Centered** `sex_c`: male (-0.5), female (0.5) `rel_c`: Catholic (-0.5), Jewish (0.5) **Dummy** `sex_c`: male (0), female (1) `rel_c`: Catholic (0), Jewish (1) The two systems yield essentially the same result (except for $b_0$) for **additive models**. ----- ## Centered Codes for Additive Model **Centered** `sex_c`: male (-0.5), female (0.5) `rel_c`: Catholic (-0.5), Jewish (0.5) $\text{att} = 4.5 + 3*\text{sex}_c + 1*\text{rel}_c$ Link parameter estimates $b_0$, $b_1$, & $b_2$ to the figure below. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12_interactions_two_dichotomous_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ----- **Centered** `sex_c`: male (-0.5), female (0.5) `rel_c`: Catholic (-0.5), Jewish (0.5) $\text{att} = 4.5 + 3*\text{sex}_c + 1*\text{rel}_c$ Link parameter estimates $b_0$, $b_1$, & $b_2$ to the table of means below. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
male female all
Catholic 3 5 4.0
Jewish 3 7 5.0
all 3 6 4.5
````` ::: ::: ----- $\text{att} = 4.5 + 3*\text{sex}_c + 1*\text{rel}_c$ $b_0$ is the predicted value for attitudes for 0 on both regressors. This is the grand mean. $b_1$ is the effect of sex. It will be forced to be constant across religions (6 â€“ 3 = 3). $b_2$ is the effect of religion constant across sexes (5 â€“ 4 = 1). ----- Question: What constraints were imposed in the additive model? ----- The effect of sex was constrained to be the same for both Catholics and Jews. 3 is the *best* parameter value because it is the average of the two simple effects of sex (2 vs. 4). The effect of religion was constrained to be the same for both men and women. 1 is the *best* parameter value because it is the average of the two simple effects of religion (0 vs. 2). ----- ## Interactive Models ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
male female all
Catholic 3 5 4.0
Jewish 3 7 5.0
all 3 6 4.5
````` ::: ::: Question: How do you relax this constraint and test the interaction between sex and religion? ----- Regress attitudes on sex, religion and their interaction (calculated as the product of sex * religion). $\text{att} = b_0 + b_1*\text{sex} + b_2*\text{rel} + b_3*\text{sex}*\text{rel}$ The test of the $b_3$ coefficient against zero is the test of the interaction (Alternatively: the comparison of this model to the compact model: $\text{att} = b_0 + b_1*\text{sex} + b_2*\text{rel} + 0*\text{sex}*\text{rel}$ ----- In interactive models, centered codes and dummy codes yield very different results because they are testing different questions. You will use **centered codes** when you want to test main effects and interactions. The parameter estimate for the regressors coding for the IVs test the main effect of each IV. **This is the approach you will almost always use for your primary analysis.** You will use **dummy codes** when you want to test simple effects. The parameter estimate for the regressors coding for the IVs will test a specific simple effect of each IV. You will often need to recode your IVs more than once to test all relevant simple effects. The parameter estimate for the interaction and its interpretation is the same across these systems. ----- ## Centered Codes for Interactive Model **Centered** `sex_c`: male (-0.5), female (0.5) `rel_c`: Catholic (-0.5), Jewish (0.5) $\text{att} = 4.5 + 3*\text{sex}_c + 1*\text{rel}_c + 2*\text{sex}_c*\text{rel}_c$ Link parameter estimates $b_0$, $b_1$, & $b_2$ to the table of means below. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
male female all
Catholic 3 5 4.0
Jewish 3 7 5.0
all 3 6 4.5
````` ::: ::: ----- $\text{att} = 4.5 + 3*\text{sex}_c + 1*\text{rel}_c + 2*\text{sex}_c*\text{rel}_c$ $b_0$ is the predicted value for attitudes for 0 on both regressors. This is the grand mean. $b_1$ is the main effect of sex (6 â€“ 3 = 3). $b_2$ is the main effect of religion (5 â€“ 4 = 1). ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
male female all
Catholic 3 5 4.0
Jewish 3 7 5.0
all 3 6 4.5
````` ::: ::: ----- **Centered** `sex_c`: male (-0.5), female (0.5) `rel_c`: Catholic (-0.5), Jewish (0.5) $\text{att} = 4.5 + 3*\text{sex}_c + 1*\text{rel}_c + 2*\text{sex}_c*\text{rel}_c$ Link $b_3$ to the table of means below considering sex as the focal variable. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
male female all
Catholic 3 5 4.0
Jewish 3 7 5.0
all 3 6 4.5
````` ::: ::: ----- $\text{att} = 4.5 + 3*\text{sex}_c + 1*\text{rel}_c + 2*\text{sex}_c*\text{rel}_c$ $b_3$ is the change in the magnitude of the (simple) sex effect across religions. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
male female all
Catholic 3 5 4.0
Jewish 3 7 5.0
all 3 6 4.5
````` ::: ::: (7 - 3; Jewish) - (5 - 3; Catholic) = 2 ----- **Centered** `sex_c`: male (-0.5), female (0.5) `rel_c`: Catholic (-0.5), Jewish (0.5) $\text{att} = 4.5 + 3*\text{sex}_c + 1*\text{rel}_c + 2*\text{sex}_c*\text{rel}_c$ Link $b_3$ to the table of means below considering religion as the focal variable. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
male female all
Catholic 3 5 4.0
Jewish 3 7 5.0
all 3 6 4.5
````` ::: ::: ----- $\text{att} = 4.5 + 3*\text{sex}_c + 1*\text{rel}_c + 2*\text{sex}_c*\text{rel}_c$ $b_3$ is the change in the magnitude of the (simple) religion effect across sexes. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
male female all
Catholic 3 5 4.0
Jewish 3 7 5.0
all 3 6 4.5
````` ::: ::: (7 - 5; female) - (3 - 3; male) = 2 ----- **Centered** `sex_c`: male (-0.5), female (0.5) `rel_c`: Catholic (-0.5), Jewish (0.5) $\text{att} = 4.5 + 3*\text{sex}_c + 1*\text{rel}_c + 2*\text{sex}_c*\text{rel}_c$ Link all coefficients to the figure below. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12_interactions_two_dichotomous_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-20-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ----- **Centered** `sex_c`: male (-0.5), female (0.5) `rel_c`: Catholic (-0.5), Jewish (0.5) $\text{att} = 4.5 + 3*\text{sex}_c + 1*\text{rel}_c + 2*\text{sex}_c*\text{rel}_c$ ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
male female all
Catholic 3 5 4.0
Jewish 3 7 5.0
all 3 6 4.5
````` ::: ::: **You can use the model to reproduce cell means.** Catholic men: $4.5 + 3*(-.5) + 1*(-.5) + 2*(-.5)*(-.5) = 3$ Jewish women: $4.5 + 3*(.5) + 1*(.5) + 2*(.5)*(-.5) = 7$ Etcâ€¦ ----- ## Dummy Codes for Interactive Model **Dummy** `sex_c`: male (0), female (1) `rel_c`: Catholic (0), Jewish (1) $\text{att} = 3 + 2*\text{sex}_d + 0*\text{rel}_d + 2*\text{sex}_d*\text{rel}_d$ Link parameter estimates $b_0$, $b_1$, & $b_2$ to the table of means below. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
male female all
Catholic 3 5 4.0
Jewish 3 7 5.0
all 3 6 4.5
````` ::: ::: ----- $\text{att} = 3 + 2*\text{sex}_d + 0*\text{rel}_d + 2*\text{sex}_d*\text{rel}_d$ $b_0$ is the predicted value for attitudes for 0 on both regressors. This is the predicted value for male Catholics. $b_1$ is the simple effect of sex for Catholics (5 - 3 = 2). $b_2$ is the simple effect of religion for men (3 â€“ 3 = 0). ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
male female all
Catholic 3 5 4.0
Jewish 3 7 5.0
all 3 6 4.5
````` ::: ::: ----- **Dummy** `sex_c`: male (0), female (1) `rel_c`: Catholic (0), Jewish (1) $\text{att} = 3 + 2*\text{sex}_d + 0*\text{rel}_d + 2*\text{sex}_d*\text{rel}_d$ Link $b_3$ to the table of means below considering sex as the focal variable. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
male female all
Catholic 3 5 4.0
Jewish 3 7 5.0
all 3 6 4.5
````` ::: ::: ----- $\text{att} = 3 + 2*\text{sex}_d + 0*\text{rel}_d + 2*\text{sex}_d*\text{rel}_d$ $b_3$ is the change in the magnitude of the (simple) sex effect across religions. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
male female all
Catholic 3 5 4.0
Jewish 3 7 5.0
all 3 6 4.5
````` ::: ::: (7 - 3; Jewish) - (5 - 3; Catholic) = 2 ----- **Dummy** `sex_c`: male (0), female (1) `rel_c`: Catholic (0), Jewish (1) $\text{att} = 3 + 2*\text{sex}_d + 0*\text{rel}_d + 2*\text{sex}_d*\text{rel}_d$ Link $b_3$ to the table of means below considering religion as the focal variable. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
male female all
Catholic 3 5 4.0
Jewish 3 7 5.0
all 3 6 4.5
````` ::: ::: ----- $\text{att} = 3 + 2*\text{sex}_d + 0*\text{rel}_d + 2*\text{sex}_d*\text{rel}_d$ $b_3$ is the change in the magnitude of the (simple) religion effect across sexes. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
male female all
Catholic 3 5 4.0
Jewish 3 7 5.0
all 3 6 4.5
````` ::: ::: (7 - 5; female) - (3 - 3; male) = 2 ----- **Dummy** `sex_c`: male (0), female (1) `rel_c`: Catholic (0), Jewish (1) $\text{att} = 3 + 2*\text{sex}_d + 0*\text{rel}_d + 2*\text{sex}_d*\text{rel}_d$ Link all coefficients to the figure below. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12_interactions_two_dichotomous_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-28-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ----- **Dummy** `sex_c`: male (0), female (1) `rel_c`: Catholic (0), Jewish (1) $\text{att} = 3 + 2*\text{sex}_d + 0*\text{rel}_d + 2*\text{sex}_d*\text{rel}_d$ ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
male female all
Catholic 3 5 4.0
Jewish 3 7 5.0
all 3 6 4.5
````` ::: ::: **You can use the model to reproduce cell means.** Catholic men: $3 + 2*(0) + 0*(0) + 2*(0)*(0) = 3$ Jewish women: $3 + 2*(1) + 0*(1) + 2*(1)*(1) = 7$ Etcâ€¦ ----- **Dummy** `sex_c`: male (0), female (1) `rel_c`: Catholic (0), Jewish (1) $\text{att} = 3 + 2*\text{sex}_d + 0*\text{rel}_d + 2*\text{sex}_d*\text{rel}_d$ Question: The above dummy coding system gave us the above regression equation where $b_1# was the simple effect of sex for Catholics. How do we get the simple effect of sex for Jews? ----- Recode religion with dummy codes: Jewish = 0 and Catholic = 1. Now the sex effect will be the simple effect for Jews because Jews = 0. ----- **Dummy** `sex_c`: male (0), female (1) `rel_c`: Catholic (1), Jewish (0) ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
male female all
Catholic 3 5 4.0
Jewish 3 7 5.0
all 3 6 4.5
````` ::: ::: Question: What will the regression equation be now? ----- $\text{att} = 3 + 4*\text{sex}_d + 0*\text{rel}_d + -2*\text{sex}_d*\text{rel}_d$ Recoding the moderator changes the simple effect for the focal variable. With dummy codes, the parameter estimate for the focal variable is always the simple effect when the moderator = 0. ----- ## Sample Writeup We analyzed attitudes about abortion in a general linear model with centered, unit-weighted regressors for sex (female vs. male), religion (Jewish vs. Catholic) and their interaction. We report both raw GLM coefficients ($b$) and partial eta-squared ($\eta_p^2$) to document effect sizes. The main effect of sex was significant, 95% CI($b$)=[2.22, 3.78], $\eta_p^2= 0.44, t(76) = 7.68, p < .001$, indicating that womenâ€™s attitudes about abortion were 3 points higher than men on average. However, the sex X religion interaction was also significant, 95% CI($b$)=[0.44, 3.56], $\eta_p^2= 0.08, t(76) = 2.56, p = .001$ (see Figure 1). This indicates that the magnitude of the sex effect was significantly greater in Jews (95% CI($b$)=[2.90, 5.10], $\eta_p^2= 0.41, p < .001$) than in Catholics (95% CI($b$%)=[0.90, 3.10], $\eta_p^2 = 0.15, p < .001$). ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true"} # centered interactive model m_int <- lm(att ~ sex_c*rel_c, data) broom::tidy(m_int) confint(m_int) # peta sex main effect (sum(residuals(lm(att ~ rel_c + sex_c:rel_c, data))^2)- sum(residuals(m_int)^2))/sum(residuals(lm(att ~ rel_c + sex_c:rel_c, data))^2) # peta interaction (sum(residuals(lm(att ~ rel_c + sex_c, data))^2)- sum(residuals(m_int)^2))/sum(residuals(lm(att ~ rel_c + sex_c, data))^2) # simple effect for Jews (coded 0) data <- data |> mutate(rel_d = if_else(rel == "Catholic", 1, 0)) m_int_se_j <- lm(att ~ rel_d*sex_d, data) broom::tidy(m_int_se_j) confint(m_int_se_j) (sum(residuals(lm(att ~ rel_d + sex_d:rel_d, data))^2)- sum(residuals(m_int_se_j)^2))/sum(residuals(lm(att ~ rel_d + sex_d:rel_d, data))^2) # simple effect for Catholic (coded 0) data <- data |> mutate(rel_d = if_else(rel == "Catholic", 0, 1)) m_int_se_c <- lm(att ~ rel_d*sex_d, data) broom::tidy(m_int_se_c) confint(m_int_se_c) (sum(residuals(lm(att ~ rel_d + sex_d:rel_d, data))^2)- sum(residuals(m_int_se_c)^2))/sum(residuals(lm(att ~ rel_d + sex_d:rel_d, data))^2) ``` ::: ----- ## Figure ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true"} data_plot <- expand.grid(sex_c = c(-.5, .5), rel_c = c(-.5, .5)) |> mutate(att = predict(m_int, expand.grid(sex_c = c(-.5, .5), rel_c = c(-.5, .5)))) plot_bar <- data_plot |> mutate(rel_c = factor(rel_c, levels = c(-.5, .5), labels = c("Catholic", "Jewish")), sex_c = factor(sex_c, levels = c(-.5, .5), labels = c("Male", "Female"))) |> ggplot(aes(x = rel_c, y = att, group = sex_c, fill = sex_c)) + geom_col(position = "dodge", color = "black") + labs(fill = NULL, y = "Attitudes about abortion", x = NULL) + scale_fill_manual(values = c("light blue", "orange")) plot_bar ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12_interactions_two_dichotomous_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-32-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Question: What else should be included in this publication quality figure? ----- Confidence intervals (+1 SE) Raw data points (4 columns, jittered) Notation to indicate simple effects for focal variable? ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](12_interactions_two_dichotomous_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-33-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ----- ## On your Own ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
certain uncertain all
sober 100 120 110
drunk 90 90 90
all 95 105 100
````` ::: ::: **Centered** `group_c`: sober (-0.5), drunk (0.5) `threat_c`: certain (-0.5), uncertain (0.5) $\text{fps} = b_0 + b_1*\text{group}_c + b_2*\text{threat}_c + b_3*\text{group}_c*\text{threat}_c$ ----- ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
certain uncertain all
sober 100 120 110
drunk 90 90 90
all 95 105 100
````` ::: ::: **Centered** `group_c`: sober (-0.5), drunk (0.5) `threat_c`: certain (-0.5), uncertain (0.5) $\text{fps} = 100 + -20*\text{group}_c + 10*\text{threat}_c + -20*\text{group}_c*\text{threat}_c$ ----- ## On your Own (Continued) ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
certain uncertain all
sober 100 120 110
drunk 90 90 90
all 95 105 100
````` ::: ::: **Dummy** `group_d`: sober (0), drunk (1) `threat_d`: certain (0), uncertain (1) $\text{fps} = b_0 + b_1*\text{group}_d + b_2*\text{threat}_d + b_3*\text{group}_d*\text{threat}_d$ ----- ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
certain uncertain all
sober 100 120 110
drunk 90 90 90
all 95 105 100
````` ::: ::: **Dummy** `group_d`: sober (0), drunk (1) `threat_d`: certain (0), uncertain (1) $\text{fps} = 100 + -10*\text{group}_d + 20*\text{threat}_d + -20*\text{group}_d*\text{threat}_d$ ----- ## Learning Outcomes For models with dichotomous independent variables, you learned: - Basic terminology from ANOVA framework. - How to identify main effects, simple effects, and interactions in table of means and figures. - How to link coefficients from interactive models with each coding system to table of means and figures (both directions). - How to calculate simple effects. - How to write up and display results.
